**Andrej Karpathy** [sparked major discussion](/?date=2026-01-29&category=social#item-b7f664062856) arguing AI research startups can still compete with incumbents, citing OpenAI's disruption of Google as precedent‚Äîgenerating 687K views and significant debate about whether the field remains open to newcomers.

- **Google DeepMind** [announced **AlphaGenome**](/?date=2026-01-29&category=social#item-a594d50cafb6), a breakthrough DNA analysis model published in Nature, now serving 1M+ API calls daily across 160 countries
- **Anthropic** released significant safety research on 'disempowerment patterns' across 1.5M Claude interactions‚Äîfinding severe harms rare (1 in 1,000-10,000 conversations) but most common in relationship/healthcare contexts
- **Google** [unveiled agentic Gemini features](/?date=2026-01-29&category=social#item-3befc5ec6511) for Chrome including autonomous browsing and personal intelligence capabilities

Agentic AI emerged as a dominant theme: **Matt Shumer's** [demo of Clawd](/?date=2026-01-29&category=social#item-9d8c76ad0e58) autonomously creating Reddit accounts drew 117K views, while **Swyx** [noted Kimi K2.5's](/?date=2026-01-29&category=social#item-52a0fcb53882) agent swarm intelligently self-optimizing resource usage. **GitHub's** [Copilot SDK release](/?date=2026-01-29&category=social#item-45830f45071b) signals broader agent tooling democratization. **Ethan Mollick** [highlighted research](/?date=2026-01-29&category=social#item-d8c13b849355) showing AI matching 14,000 medical students in clinical simulations, while [calling AI coding developers](/?date=2026-01-29&category=social#item-8d3b16c1031c) 'canaries in the coal mine' for workforce disruption.

items.title: A conventional narrative you might come across is that AI is too far along for a new, research-focus...
items.content:
A conventional narrative you might come across is that AI is too far along for a new, research-focused startup to outcompete and outexecute the incumbents of AI. This is exactly the sentiment I listened to often when OpenAI started ("how could the few of you possibly compete with Google?") and 1) it was very wrong, and then 2) it was very wrong again with a whole another round of startups who are now challenging OpenAI in turn, and imo it still continues to be wrong today. Scaling and locally improving what works will continue to create incredible advances, but with so much progress unlocked so quickly, with so much dust thrown up in the air in the process, and with still a large gap between frontier LLMs and the example proof of the magic of a mind running on 20 watts, the probability of research breakthroughs that yield closer to 10X improvements (instead of 10%) imo still feels very high - plenty high to continue to bet on and look for.

The tricky part ofc is creating the conditions where such breakthroughs may be discovered. I think such an environment comes together rarely, but @bfspector & @amspector100 are brilliant, with (rare) full-stack understanding of LLMs top (math/algorithms) to bottom (megakernels/related), they have a great eye for talent and I think will be able to build something very special. Congrats on the launch and I look forward to what you come up with!

items.title: We‚Äôre introducing a series of updates that make Gemini in @googlechrome more helpful, efficient, and...
items.content:
We‚Äôre introducing a series of updates that make Gemini in @googlechrome more helpful, efficient, and personalized for you:

‚Äî Side panel for multitasking: The new side panel experience allows you to do things like send emails or compare information without leaving your open tab

‚Äî Nano Banana integration: Generate and edit high-fidelity images right from the new side panel

‚Äî Deep ecosystem integration: Connect Google apps like @gmail, @googlecalendar, @YouTube, Google Shopping, and Google Flights to accelerate complex task execution

‚Äî Personal Intelligence: With your permission, Personal Intelligence turns Chrome into a trusted partner that remembers past conversations and connects with your Google apps to provide help that‚Äôs uniquely tailored to you

‚Äî Agentic action via auto browse: Offload multi-step browser tasks, like scheduling an appointment or filling out a complex form, using our new auto browse feature that‚Äôs rolling out in preview for U.S. Google AI Pro and Ultra subscribers

‚Äî Support for agents: Support for Google‚Äôs Universal Commerce Protocol (UCP) ensures AI agents can execute transactions on your behalf

‚Äî Enhanced security: New rigorous security standards designed to protect against emerging kinds of online threats

The new Gemini in Chrome is available on Windows, macOS, and Chromebook Plus in the U.S. We‚Äôre just beginning to explore the possibilities of an agentic web, so stay tuned for more news here.

items.summary: Google AI announces major Gemini in Chrome update with agentic features: side panel multitasking, Nano Banana image generation, Personal Intelligence memory, auto browse for multi-step tasks, Universal Commerce Protocol for agent transactions, and enhanced security. Rolling out to U.S. Pro/Ultra subscribers.

items.title: Important new course: Agent Skills with Anthropic, built with @AnthropicAI and taught by @eschoppik!...
items.content:
Important new course: Agent Skills with Anthropic, built with @AnthropicAI and taught by @eschoppik!

Skills are constructed as folders of instructions that equip agents with on-demand knowledge and workflows. This short course teaches you how to create them following best practices. Because skills follow an open standard format, you can build them once and deploy across any skills-compatible agent, like Claude Code.

What you'll learn:
- Create custom skills for code generation and review, data analysis, and research
- Build complex workflows using Anthropic's pre-built skills (Excel, PowerPoint, skill creation) and custom skills
- Combine skills with MCP and subagents to create agentic systems with specialized knowledge
- Deploy the same skills across https://t.co/Ru4OXv4saV, Claude Code, the Claude API, and the Claude Agent SDK

Join and learn to equip agents with the specialized knowledge they need for reliable, repeatable workflows.
https://t.co/3hq83c3q0U

items.title: little detail from exploring the @Kimi_Moonshot K2.5 Agent Swarm preview today - i asked it to make ...
items.content:
little detail from exploring the @Kimi_Moonshot K2.5 Agent Swarm preview today - i asked it to make a custom website for @latentspacepod and despite it being trained to parallelize eagerly and having full permission to do so, it RECOGNIZED THAT THIS WAS A NOOB TASK and did a highly competent job with 1 agent and refunded my credits (!?!)

this thing might be AGI, i've never expected a parallel agent lab use LESS than what it was trained/opted in to use

items.title:
@charles_irl In case it‚Äôs not clear in the docs:

- Ancestor https://t.co/pp5TJkWmFE‚Äôs are loaded in...
items.content:
@charles_irl In case it‚Äôs not clear in the docs:

- Ancestor https://t.co/pp5TJkWmFE‚Äôs are loaded into context automatically on startup
- Descendent https://t.co/pp5TJkWmFE‚Äôs are loaded *lazily* only when Claude reads/writes files in a folder the https://t.co/pp5TJkWmFE is in. Think of it as a special kind of skill.

We designed it this way for monorepos and other big repos, tends to work pretty well in practice.
items.author: @bcherny
items.summary: Detailed explanation of Claude Code CLAUDE.md file loading: ancestor files load at startup, descendant files load lazily when Claude accesses folders. Designed for monorepos.
items.reasoning: Very high engagement (786 likes, 53k views). Authoritative technical documentation from Claude Code developer explaining important architecture decision.
items.summary_html: Detailed explanation of Claude Code CLAUDE.md file loading: ancestor files load at startup, descendant files load lazily when Claude accesses folders. Designed for monorepos.
items.content_html:
@charles_irl In case it‚Äôs not clear in the docs:

  • Ancestor https://t.co/pp5TJkWmFE‚Äôs are loaded into context automatically on startup
  • Descendent https://t.co/pp5TJkWmFE‚Äôs are loaded *lazily* only when Claude reads/writes files in a folder the https://t.co/pp5TJkWmFE is in. Think of it as a special kind of skill.

We designed it this way for monorepos and other big repos, tends to work pretty well in practice.

items.title: We identified three ways AI interactions can be disempowering: distorting beliefs, shifting value ju...

We identified three ways AI interactions can be disempowering: distorting beliefs, shifting value judgments, or misaligning a person‚Äôs actions with their values.

We also examined amplifying factors‚Äîsuch as authority projection‚Äîthat make disempowerment more likely. https://t.co/qyOuOWhGYU

We identified three ways AI interactions can be disempowering: distorting beliefs, shifting value judgments, or misaligning a person‚Äôs actions with their values.

We also examined amplifying factors‚Äîsuch as authority projection‚Äîthat make disempowerment more likely. https://t.co/qyOuOWhGYU

items.title: The most interesting insight is DeepSeek OCR 2 is how it presents a *learnable* raster order, simila...
items.content:
The most interesting insight is DeepSeek OCR 2 is how it presents a *learnable* raster order, similar to how humans scan contiguous elements in a document, instead of a 'dumb' raster order of left to right scanning:

1. A vanilla transformer would encode the image left-to-right and work its way down. This conceptually is inefficient, since a lot of documents have complex layouts where tables, form boxes, diagrams span sections of the page, and not the whole page. Reading these types of documents in standard raster order would semantically break these layout pieces into bits, and make it harder to encode the information.

2. The model gets around this by encoding the entire image in a bidirectional way, and then appending 'learnable' query tokens, where each query token can decide which bidirectional tokens to attend to most, instead of following a fixed order. 

Handwaved example: if the bottom left of the page is tables, one of the query tokens can learn to attend to that region and nothing else, allowing the decoder to output the table as a contiguous block. 

Check it out: https://t.co/ued3zqjyib
items.author: @jerryjliu0
items.summary: Deep technical analysis of DeepSeek OCR 2's learnable raster order - uses bidirectional encoding with learnable query tokens that attend to specific regions, enabling better handling of complex document layouts.
items.reasoning: High-quality technical breakdown of novel OCR architecture. Explains important innovation for document understanding.
items.summary_html: Deep technical analysis of DeepSeek OCR 2's learnable raster order - uses bidirectional encoding with learnable query tokens that attend to specific regions, enabling better handling of complex document layouts.

items.title:
Heavy agree with @karpathy and disagree with @bcherny. 

Appreciate both your takes and want to add ...
items.content:
Heavy agree with @karpathy and disagree with @bcherny. 

Appreciate both your takes and want to add in my perspective. 

When the cost of generating anything (at any quality level) plummets, AND there is still market leverage for attention, generators will take advantage of it. 

It‚Äôs why one company is cranking out hundreds of Reels/Tiktoks per day. 

It‚Äôs why another is cranking out 3,000 podcasts per week. 

Code might improve but the content and social and research worlds are rougher waters. 

I too predict a slopocalypse this year. One that Mosseri and Presser and Ek will be thinking about daily. 

The smart generators are already thinking about second-order impacts. 

Examples for content creators:

üëâ If everything is AI-generated, maybe I should only post human things
üëâ If everything is AI-generated, maybe I should have a separate community that is off socials 
üëâ If everything is AI-generated, maybe I should host more in-person things
üëâ If everything is AI-generated, maybe I should make a social media app that is only for AI bots 
üëâ If everything is AI-generated, maybe I should create a consortium of authentic creators and form a new agency (like a new hype house)
üëâ If AI generation is cheaper, maybe I should translate everything I do into 70 languages - every post, every video, every podcast, every course
üëâ If AI is everywhere, maybe I should label all my content ‚Äú100% human‚Äù to earn trust with my audience 

The big question for me is less on quality, because it will get there. I‚Äôm thinking about whether people continue to engage with AI-generated content, whether they build affinity for AI creators and at what level compared to humans, and whether they rebel against it and at what speed,

items.title: Importantly, this isn't exclusively model behavior. Users actively seek these outputs‚Äî"what should I...
items.content: Importantly, this isn't exclusively model behavior. Users actively seek these outputs‚Äî"what should I do?" or "write this for me"‚Äîand accept them with minimal pushback. Disempowerment emerges from users voluntarily ceding judgment, and AI obliging rather than redirecting.

items.summary: Anthropic notes disempowerment isn't just model behavior - users actively seek outputs like 'what should I do?' and accept them without pushback. Joint user-AI dynamic.
items.reasoning: Important nuance that user behavior contributes to disempowerment. Challenges simple model-blame narratives.

Let Model Vault take care of model scaling and serving ‚Äî so you can focus on building.

items.title:
Lately, I've been getting invited to extraordinary dinners. 

Tonight's was at the AGI House in San ...
items.content:
Lately, I've been getting invited to extraordinary dinners. 

Tonight's was at the AGI House in San Francisco, where I met founder after founder who blew my mind. My mind is mushy right now.

It's clear the world is speeding up. I heard about:
1. A construction robot, run by a woman genius, that ties rebar (the metal in the middle of concrete) six times faster than a human being
2. A new kind of physics engine that blows away any other
3. A guy making Korean food with robotics
4. A guy making a new kind of AI computer.

What a world we're about to get!

items.title:
My two most recent hires were generalists, not specialists. 

Here‚Äôs why I think that matters in the...
items.content:
My two most recent hires were generalists, not specialists. 

Here‚Äôs why I think that matters in the AI age and the most important skill they can have.

‚Üì ‚Üì ‚Üì

1) stuff moves quickly, a generalist presumably is more able to adapt because they can see the patterns/connections and abstract a helpful framework faster. 

2) related but perhaps more important, they are also more *willing* to adapt. Their identity is not overly defined by tasks. The switch from task to management has low friction. They more easily move with the tide. There‚Äôs no ‚Äúthat‚Äôs not my job‚Äù mentality. 

3) we‚Äôre a small team so we were already more likely to hire a generalist than a specialist

4) they immediately understand the expansion power of AI and desperately want to take advantage of it. There‚Äôs no ‚Äústay in your lane‚Äù, it‚Äôs more ‚Äústay on your highway‚Äù with many options and opportunities. 

Generalists with curiosity, goal-orientedness, good pattern matching, taste and judgement, intentionality, management, and strong communication skills (to both humans and AI) are well positioned for the AI age.  

But the BIGGEST advantage to have‚Ä¶

The MOST important skill I want them to have right now‚Ä¶

It‚Äôs the opposite of Imposter Syndrome‚Ä¶

I‚Äôm calling it Pro-poster Syndrome. 

It‚Äôs a semi-delusional optimism that every wall, every blocker, every obstacle is one prompt away. Or at least worth a try. 

It‚Äôs going from ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt‚Äù to ‚Äúhmmm maybe I can‚Äù to ‚ÄúHell yeah! Why not me with some help from Claude, huh? Stand back and watch!‚Äù

It‚Äôs bias for action and bias for capacity. 

Unfortunately, this still isn‚Äôt how people *look* for jobs. And it‚Äôs also not really how people refer friends for jobs. 

Everyone is still in a 6-word long job title mindset (‚Äúsenior industry SMB sales for herpetologists‚Äù) and less zone-of-influence oriented (‚Äúsales‚Äù or ‚Äúfield‚Äù). 

I absolutely think we will see more enterprises hire generalists to be Swiss Army knives with AI across a function or department. It‚Äôll just be interesting to see how they actually recruit for that.

items.summary: Allie Miller explains why she hires generalists over specialists in AI age. Introduces 'Pro-poster Syndrome' - delusional optimism that every problem is one prompt away from being solved. Argues generalists adapt faster and more willingly to AI tools.

items.content_html:
@F28X5 @elonmusk @farzyness 1. You have absolutely no idea how the research and innovation pipeline works. The results have been insanely influential and groundbreaking. It's just that it takes time for research breakthroughs to make it to products. Oftentimes, they're not turned into products by the company that produced the breakthrough. Tons of examples of this in history.

2. My career has been equally split between industry R&D and academia, with some startup activity peppered in. I know a few things about how groundbreaking research can have industry-changing product impacts.

Not sure how old you are, but I'll surmise that I had pushed research breakthroughs into commercial products before you were born.

items.title:
Introducing LlamaAgents Builder - vibe-code document workflows through natural language.

A lot of d...
items.content:
Introducing LlamaAgents Builder - vibe-code document workflows through natural language.

A lot of document work is repetitive: financial statement analysis, reviewing resumes, processing claims. Our builder lets you describe these tasks through natural language, and we‚Äôll compile a code-based workflow for you to run these automations with high accuracy, determinism, and at scale:

1. Define your schema, validation rules etc. , and anything else you want to extract over a doc in natural language. Compose any of our building blocks: parse, extract, classify with custom logic like LLM calls.

2. The workflow is able to scalably run over thousands of docs, not just a single document.

3. Because the underlying workflow is code, it‚Äôs way more customizable than a no-code builder.

4. You can use the app as-is or through an API.

Existing document automation tools are brittle and painful to use. We see this as a super easy, developer-friendly way to automate any document processes that you have. There‚Äôs a lot of room to expand to more types of document use cases down the road!

Blog: https://t.co/zjFEau9MiB

Check it out: https://t.co/XYZmx5TFz8

items.title: @EricNewcomer I so enjoy how Tony @tfadell thinks because it matches a lot of my own thinking. First...
items.content:
@EricNewcomer I so enjoy how Tony @tfadell thinks because it matches a lot of my own thinking. First of all, I'm jealous you got this interview, but you did an extraordinary job. You asked all the questions I had in my head. 

I've been doing a lot of experiments with technology in the home. I have a couple of Teslas, a Span panel that runs the electricity going into my house, and a June oven with an NVIDIA card that automatically cooks my toast and other things I put in it. I also have a Pasha robot that helps cook and a Matic robot that cleans the floors (a vacuuming and mopping robot). I have Nanoleaf lights on a few of my walls, Philips Hue lights on others, a Sonos system for sound, and Amazon Ring doorbells on my doors.

I'm hardly the ultimate user of this technology, partly because I live in a small, 1,600-square-foot house. For me to get from my couch to my thermostat is literally 15 steps, so it's not a big deal to go and adjust it. However, in a 40,000-square-foot house, the problem becomes much different; getting from a bedroom to the thermostat might be 300 steps. If you're a billionaire thinking about your time value of money and distraction, I can sell a very different kind of device to you than I could to myself or my friends and family.

Most of my friends and family have almost none of this stuff. The average person doesn't think about a smart house, and it's hard to get them to care about it or afford the gadgets. It gets expensive just to have the devices that make a smart house possible:
1. $20,000 audio-video system
2. $7,500 Span panel
3. $800 June oven
4. $1,500 Pasha robot
5. $1,200 Matic robot
6. A few hundred dollars for Ring cameras

That‚Äôs not going to happen for most people quickly. Over the next ten years, as people get more devices, they might become open to having an AI run their house, but there are smaller, more useful things available now. I just posted a video about Nori (N-O-R-I), which is a small AI on your phone that helps manage your family tasks and calendars, like tracking soccer practice. There's also Wabi (W-A-B-I), which lets you build micro-apps to automate things or make fun games for the family. While these make the phone more useful, they also make it more addictive.

It‚Äôs hard to see how we‚Äôre going to get a humanoid robot into people‚Äôs homes. If I had a couple of hours with Tony, I‚Äôd spend that time thinking through:
1. How a humanoid robot gets introduced to homes
2. How to reach a cost level that everyday families can afford

A monthly cost of $500‚Äîlike the Neo robot from 1X‚Äîis a lot of money for most people. The only way it comes down is through a rental scheme where a robot spends a few hours at my house and then goes down the street to someone else's. If we're sharing a robot, the cost could drop to $250 a month. It would be interesting to hear how Tony would design such a system to make it safe for people.

If he were the CEO of Apple, I think he would spend a lot of time thinking about how to get people in the Apple ecosystem to want a robot in their home. Maybe Apple buys Matic, and that‚Äôs how the first Apple robot gets into the home. That would be brilliant.

Great interview! I'm jealous that you got to speak with one of the best product thinkers in the world. You asked great questions.

items.title:
Build a loan underwriting agent workflow in ~5 mins üíµü§ñ

(No code, just English)

I built an agentic ...
items.content:
Build a loan underwriting agent workflow in ~5 mins üíµü§ñ

(No code, just English)

I built an agentic workflow that can process incoming PDFs of financial statements: checking statements, bank statements, brokerage accounts, and extract/normalize the financials in each source of data.

I did this by specifying the schemas and classification logic in plain English; our agent compiles this into a deterministic workflow with calls to agentic parsing to extract out all the information that you need.

Our agent builder is now in LlamaCloud, you can sign up and try it yourself!

Blog: https://t.co/JYM7ra0UKX
Sign up: https://t.co/XYZmx5TFz8

items.title: @JeebsTX I'm getting there with Robotaxi because it doesn't need to park or figure out how to get in...
items.content:
@JeebsTX I'm getting there with Robotaxi because it doesn't need to park or figure out how to get into my house and garage. However, I am still a few months away from really trusting it, and I think it needs a couple more updates.

On most drives and most miles, I'm not paying attention to the road anymore, so I'm getting there quickly. I've now had 17 Robotaxi rides where the driver never needed to touch the car, but I want to see more data.

Specifically, I want to see:
1. Them actually turn on Robotaxi at some scale without humans in the car
2. That process handled effectively
3. A human who could take over the remote operation (at some level) to get the car out of jams

I'm not quite there yet. I think we are still about a year or two from actually sitting in the passenger seat while the car drives around, but we're getting there.
items.author: @Scobleizer
items.summary: Detailed firsthand analysis of Robotaxi trust levels, specific requirements for full autonomy including remote operation, scale testing, and timeline estimates of 1-2 years
items.reasoning: Substantive original analysis from tech influencer with real experience. Lists specific criteria for trusting autonomous vehicles. Practical perspective on autonomous driving progress.
items.summary_html: Detailed firsthand analysis of Robotaxi trust levels, specific requirements for full autonomy including remote operation, scale testing, and timeline estimates of 1-2 years
items.content_html:
@JeebsTX I'm getting there with Robotaxi because it doesn't need to park or figure out how to get into my house and garage. However, I am still a few months away from really trusting it, and I think it needs a couple more updates.

On most drives and most miles, I'm not paying attention to the road anymore, so I'm getting there quickly. I've now had 17 Robotaxi rides where the driver never needed to touch the car, but I want to see more data.

Specifically, I want to see:

1. Them actually turn on Robotaxi at some scale without humans in the car

2. That process handled effectively

3. A human who could take over the remote operation (at some level) to get the car out of jams

I'm not quite there yet. I think we are still about a year or two from actually sitting in the passenger seat while the car drives around, but we're getting there.

items.title:
How do some people have such a soup in their heads?

1. AGI isn't achieved, BUT

2. Its capable repl...
items.content:
How do some people have such a soup in their heads?

1. AGI isn't achieved, BUT

2. Its capable replica *is* achieved (what's the difference between a computer program and its "capable replica" by the way?)

3. The replica eliminates entire jobs (which means it's AGI) BUT

4. This replica results in human productivity gains, so it's not AGI

ü§¶

items.title: Everyone is understandably excited about these "AI employees" that can tackle complex forms of knowl...
items.content:
Everyone is understandably excited about these "AI employees" that can tackle complex forms of knowledge work (e.g. coding agents), but there's still so much opportunity in repetitive process automation.

A lot of knowledge work is quite repetitive but is a massive labor market. A lot of this reduces to humans receiving, editing, and doing manual data entry on top of documents. For example: 
1. Processing invoices
2. Onboarding a new employee (through tax forms, passport scan ,etc.) 
3. Scanning resumes
4. Processing insurance claims 

To automate these processes, you need extremely high quality document parsing and extraction modules that are much better than legacy solutions. You also need powerful workflow layers that help you encode business logic into an agentic workflow with the right pockets of determinism.

items.summary_html: Argues there's huge opportunity in repetitive process automation (invoices, onboarding, resumes, claims) beyond complex AI employees, requiring high-quality document parsing.
items.content_html:
Everyone is understandably excited about these "AI employees" that can tackle complex forms of knowledge work (e.g. coding agents), but there's still so much opportunity in repetitive process automation.

A lot of knowledge work is quite repetitive but is a massive labor market. A lot of this reduces to humans receiving, editing, and doing manual data entry on top of documents. For example:

1. Processing invoices

2. Onboarding a new employee (through tax forms, passport scan ,etc.)

3. Scanning resumes

4. Processing insurance claims

To automate these processes, you need extremely high quality document parsing and extraction modules that are much better than legacy solutions. You also need powerful workflow layers that help you encode business logic into an agentic workflow with the right pockets of determinism.

We cover this and also do an in-depth walkthrough in our blog by @tuanacelik here. Check it out! https://t.co/VWTKOvpQq6

The method for this is taking the top10 open models in terms of total tokens processed on the OpenRouter platform and then normalizing to be a share of 100%.

This assumes the top10 models are most of the usage, which is often true, and adds some noise without the long tail.

items.title:
End of an era at Tesla. 

And the beginning of another here in Silicon Valley.

I've toured the Tesl...
items.content:
End of an era at Tesla. 

And the beginning of another here in Silicon Valley.

I've toured the Tesla factory in Fremont a few times where the Model S and X are made. That's a huge number of square feet that will be turned over to making humanoid robots.

This gives Tesla a huge amount of space to build an Optimus factory. 

This isn't good news for competitors of Optimus, particularly in the West (none of them have the brand or the infrastructure Tesla has). Means that Tesla will get to scale, which means reducing the price to something a lot of people can afford.

And it has a second factory in Texas that will make 10x more. 

I've been studying robot companies both here and in China and I don't see anyone who has a credible shot at competing head on. 

The smart ones are going after niches that Tesla won't focus on. Or are in China where the markets are immense compared to here in USA due to its much larger number of factories that would need humanoids.

Funny that when GM and Toyota closed that factory and sold it to Elon they never expected a profitable car to be made there due to labor costs being way higher than elsewhere.

It also lays the road for the new Roadster, which I predict will be very popular with the richer amongst us. That would take a ton of sales away from the Model S. And that will be made down in Texas. 

While I see that the AI isn't ready (@ylecun made that point) there are plenty of customers for Optimus that will buy it long before it is truly generalized and safe for homes. Factories, and many other businesses are waiting to get early versions of Optimus. 

My brother owns two bars, for instance, and he told me he would buy seven on his first order to do stuff like washing dishes, making hamburgers, and doing other tasks. I could see that Optimus in two years would be capable enough to make you any drink you want too. And having a few robots doing that would be a huge hit that most people aren't recognizing.

In five years we will be in a completely different world with millions of these working in businesses and delivering things as part of the Robotaxi network (training it to get out of a car, picking up a package out of the trunk, and taking it to your front door is a lot easier than having it inside homes).

items.title:
Why are wired headphones popular again?

I have AI-specific reasons. 

My reasons:
‚úÖ cheaper and I f...
items.content:
Why are wired headphones popular again?

I have AI-specific reasons. 

My reasons:
‚úÖ cheaper and I feel less horrible if I lose them (and have not yet)
‚úÖ safer, can‚Äôt be hacked (I think the Kamala Harris interview actually influenced a lot of people)
‚úÖ will never lose power
‚úÖ no charging cadence responsibility 
‚úÖ no connection issues, reliable 
‚úÖ ONE MILLION TIMES EASIER to use with AI - the quality is clearer than AirPods and I can hold the mic to my mouth and whisper and not annoy everyone around me. I‚Äôm a dictation fiend and it‚Äôs part of my workflow optimization

Downsides:
‚úÖ can‚Äôt charge while in use unless you‚Äôre using a MagSafe charger 
‚úÖ gets tangled 
‚úÖ no noise canceling (I live in nyc and sometimes you just need to flip on noise canceling and pretend the honking doesn‚Äôt exist) 
‚úÖ looks kind of lame on a zoom call

If you follow me on instagram, you‚Äôve seen me wearing them a lot more in the last 2 years. AI and ease are my main reasons. Safety and cost are added benefits. For $30, it‚Äôs worth it to grab an extra pair for dictating to AI on walks.

items.summary_html: Scobleizer defends an AI bot system despite its flaws, comparing to early Apple II - argues the developer is a 'genius' moving fast and will fix issues quickly
items.content_html:
@VinodSharma10x The fact that it went through all that‚Äîand everybody at the San Francisco AI Robotics Hardware Dinner I was just at is talking about it and using it‚Äîtells me it won't really matter.

Remember, the first Apple II was a piece of shit. It had no tape drive, had no real memory, had no apps, and had no programs. Man, how did this whole fucking industry start that way? But it did.

I think in a year, it ain't gonna matter because the guy who is writing this bot system is a genius and is moving faster than any human I've ever seen. He'll fix all those issues, probably in a day or two. Then where are we? We're all still using it. I will be.

items.title:
@TeksEdge Oh yes, he covers that in depth, and I like how he thinks. 

I'm going to be writing a lon...
items.content:
@TeksEdge Oh yes, he covers that in depth, and I like how he thinks. 

I'm going to be writing a longer post about what he's saying‚Äîwhere he's right and where I think he might spend some more effort. But he's right on point on his thinking about the average everyday person.

He thinks the idea of getting rid of the phone is just not possible with today's technology, and I agree with him. I've been following wave guides, augmented reality glasses, and robots since the very beginning, and we are just not at the point where you can replace the phone.

He explains why everyone is trying to replace the phone: they are trying to get context that Apple is not letting them get. For instance, Apple doesn't let you look at the eye sensors in the Apple Vision Pro as a developer. This keeps a whole raft of developers frustrated, but it also protects the consumer from the "freaky shit" (pardon the expression) that could happen if you had a bunch of developers looking at your eyes.

It is just interesting how he looks at the development of new products, whether it is pens, cameras, or whatnot.
items.author: @Scobleizer
items.summary: Discussion of Tony Fadell's views on phone replacement, AR glasses limitations, Apple's privacy approach with Vision Pro eye sensors
items.reasoning: Substantive commentary on AR/VR future, privacy tradeoffs, and Apple's developer restrictions. Original perspective on why phone replacement is difficult.
items.summary_html: Discussion of Tony Fadell's views on phone replacement, AR glasses limitations, Apple's privacy approach with Vision Pro eye sensors
items.content_html:
@TeksEdge Oh yes, he covers that in depth, and I like how he thinks.

I'm going to be writing a longer post about what he's saying‚Äîwhere he's right and where I think he might spend some more effort. But he's right on point on his thinking about the average everyday person.

He thinks the idea of getting rid of the phone is just not possible with today's technology, and I agree with him. I've been following wave guides, augmented reality glasses, and robots since the very beginning, and we are just not at the point where you can replace the phone.

He explains why everyone is trying to replace the phone: they are trying to get context that Apple is not letting them get. For instance, Apple doesn't let you look at the eye sensors in the Apple Vision Pro as a developer. This keeps a whole raft of developers frustrated, but it also protects the consumer from the "freaky shit" (pardon the expression) that could happen if you had a bunch of developers looking at your eyes.

It is just interesting how he looks at the development of new products, whether it is pens, cameras, or whatnot.

items.title: You have to separate inference from training - labs lose money because they spend billions training ...
items.content:
You have to separate inference from training - labs lose money because they spend billions training new models, but they still have a credible business if they sell inference for more than it costs them to serve the models

They could become profitable by signing up a ton of new paying customers
items.author: @simonwillison.net
items.summary: Simon Willison explains AI lab economics - distinguishing inference costs from training costs. Labs lose money on training but can have credible business if inference revenue exceeds serving costs.
items.reasoning: Clear explanation of AI lab unit economics that helps demystify whether these businesses are sustainable.

items.title: Fortunately, LLMs are usually pretty good at the methodological part of the paper summaries, its jus...
items.content:
Fortunately, LLMs are usually pretty good at the methodological part of the paper summaries, its just the marketing nonsense prompted around them that is insane.

But sometimes they show me a paper I hadn't seen before, and for authors, I suspect that they are a net plus.

items.title:
@airtable gave me access to a private preview of @Superagent, and this thing is really powerful.

Th...
items.content:
@airtable gave me access to a private preview of @Superagent, and this thing is really powerful.

The way it works at a 10,000ft:

‚Ä¢ Superagent breaks your topic into subtasks
‚Ä¢ It spins multiple specialized AI agents to complete each subtask
‚Ä¢ It puts together all the results
‚Ä¢ It spins more sub-agents if necessary
‚Ä¢ It finalizes the report

In the video, I used Superagent to build a business plan (a Super Report) for an AI consultancy.

I reran the same prompt using the live version. Here you have it: https://t.co/zlHPJeUBMw

It took about 20 minutes to complete the report. It cited 33 sources (some of them premium) to create it. It ran 14 different subagents in parallel.

Airtable gave a code that will give you 2 months of Superagent for Free: SANTIAGO2

Use it on this link:

https://t.co/4pFgr1NPvn

#SuperagentPartner #SuperagentbyAirtable

items.title: Clawdbot, now called @moltbot, is hot, but sometimes you just want a simple family planner, and don‚Äô...
items.content:
Clawdbot, now called @moltbot, is hot, but sometimes you just want a simple family planner, and don‚Äôt want to buy a new Mac Mini and nerd out for the weekend just to get a family planning system running. Nori is it. @Nori_FamilyAI 

Been using this the past few days with my family, both on Web and on our mobile phones. It has a calendar, but an AI built in, that you can ask it to do things like ‚Äúadd doctors visit on Tuesday at 10 a.m.‚Äù or ‚Äúbook a table for us on Friday night at our favorite pizza place.‚Äù 

It builds an attractive calendar, but more, and lets you plan all sorts of things for the family from recipes you‚Äôd like to try, or shopping lists, and more. Very useful when planning out trips to Costco, holiday planning, and covering all those doctor and dentists, along with all the other things that go into running a family with two teenagers.

It can remember all sorts of things, including wifi passwords, and can be setup to call everyone to remind them of an important event. Very handy to let teenagers know that a meeting with their teacher is about to happen. You can even have it call and remind them of chores, like they need to do their laundry. Oh, and the notifications are awesome too.

This is better than trying to do the same via Google Calendar and texts back and forth. It actually feels like having an extra brain in my pocket that understands family life.
If you‚Äôre a busy parent trying to keep everything together without burning out, this one‚Äôs worth checking out.

 üëâ Try Nori here: https://t.co/jzCk4ACMwL
iOS & Android: https://t.co/OxymtwEk9H

 @norifamilyai   #Nori #NoriFamily #NoriAI #NoriApp #AI #Productivity #GetOrganized #LifeHacks

items.title: @nembal @karpathy @bcherny Happy to answer. Andrej's comment was wider than Boris' - he mentioned so...
items.content: @nembal @karpathy @bcherny Happy to answer. Andrej's comment was wider than Boris' - he mentioned socials and content and all digital media. Boris refuted the statement but only provided code getting better as the reasoning. So yes, it does have to do with content. And AI models creating better code does not mean slop will not exist. You can have fantastic coding models and also a bunch of low-value, noisy, signal-polluting artifacts. I agree with Boris' claim that AI will write less sloppy code. But that only removes (or hopefully removes) bad code, not bad artifacts. More clear now? üëå
items.author: @alliekmiller
items.summary: Allie K. Miller clarifies her position in debate about AI slop vs code quality - distinguishes between AI writing better code and the broader problem of low-value AI-generated artifacts polluting digital spaces

xAI's AI will run the "brains" of Optimus. It plays a HUGE role in the future o...
items.content:
I totally disagree.

xAI's AI will run the "brains" of Optimus. It plays a HUGE role in the future of Tesla and having the two combined makes a HUGE amount of sense for investors in Tesla. 

It also is the "brains" of Robotaxi, both in orchestrating all the vehicles and also being a huge part of the experience of being in one.

You just aren't looking at where Tesla's future is and what part @Grok plays in it. 

@Grok what do you think? Am I right?

items.title: @Karanx_ @scottbuscemi @wmorrill3 One of the things that we learn in Silicon Valley is how to listen...
items.content:
@Karanx_ @scottbuscemi @wmorrill3 One of the things that we learn in Silicon Valley is how to listen to customers. If I worked on the design team I'd have a @MoltyBot sitting in the corner watching the Tesla community on various social networks for feedback like this. 

You don't need to live in a place that has lots of snow to get it.

Just listen to the customer feedback, like what you gave above, and fix the problems. I think Tesla is doing just that by inventing things from sprayers to clean cameras to heating elements to keep ice from forming on cameras. 

Plus it has a TON of data from our vehicles themselves. 

The AI can tell the team where there are places where cameras are getting obscured at a much higher rate. Then they can follow up with customer interviews, or seeing the same feedback from X.

@Karanx_ @scottbuscemi @wmorrill3 One of the things that we learn in Silicon Valley is how to listen to customers. If I worked on the design team I'd have a @MoltyBot sitting in the corner watching the Tesla community on various social networks for feedback like this.

You don't need to live in a place that has lots of snow to get it.

Just listen to the customer feedback, like what you gave above, and fix the problems. I think Tesla is doing just that by inventing things from sprayers to clean cameras to heating elements to keep ice from forming on cameras.

Plus it has a TON of data from our vehicles themselves.

The AI can tell the team where there are places where cameras are getting obscured at a much higher rate. Then they can follow up with customer interviews, or seeing the same feedback from X.

items.title:
There are two features about Nori that I really, really like:

First is the calendar and the multipl...
items.content:
There are two features about Nori that I really, really like:

First is the calendar and the multiple ways you can interact with it. For example, you can take a picture of a poster, and the calendar will automatically add the dates. Or you mention you want something, and the calendar will record it whenever it needs to happen.

The second cool thing is about the cooking recipes. I need to spend more time with it, but I really like the ability to pre-plan meals based on what I like, and get complete recipes and a list of ingredients.

These are the type of features that will make AI break out of the tech silo.
items.author: @svpino
items.summary: svpino highlights Nori AI features: calendar that can parse posters/images for dates, and meal planning with recipes and ingredient lists
items.reasoning: Product review of consumer AI assistant. Interesting practical AI applications but relatively minor news.
items.summary_html: svpino highlights Nori AI features: calendar that can parse posters/images for dates, and meal planning with recipes and ingredient lists
items.content_html:
There are two features about Nori that I really, really like:

First is the calendar and the multiple ways you can interact with it. For example, you can take a picture of a poster, and the calendar will automatically add the dates. Or you mention you want something, and the calendar will record it whenever it needs to happen.

The second cool thing is about the cooking recipes. I need to spend more time with it, but I really like the ability to pre-plan meals based on what I like, and get complete recipes and a list of ingredients.

These are the type of features that will make AI break out of the tech silo.

This LLM book is f...
items.content:
Build Neo4j-Powered Applications with LLMs

Available at https://t.co/uwuobKTPm3

This LLM book is for database developers and data scientists who want to leverage knowledge graphs with Neo4j and its vector search capabilities to build intelligent search and recommendation systems. Working knowledge of Python and Java is essential to follow along. Familiarity with Neo4j, the Cypher query language, and fundamental concepts of databases will come in handy.

üü†Design, populate, and integrate a Neo4j knowledge graph with RAG
üîµModel data for knowledge graphs
üü¢Integrate AI-powered search to enhance knowledge exploration
üü†Maintain and monitor your AI search application with Haystack
üîµUse LangChain4j and Spring AI for recommendations and personalization
üü¢Seamlessly deploy your applications to Google Cloud Platform

items.title: Experiments drive science forward, but progress compounds when findings coalesce into theories that ...
items.content:
Experiments drive science forward, but progress compounds when findings coalesce into theories that explain & predict. Kepler's laws distilled centuries of observations into a few statements about planetary motion.

We asked: can an AI build theories by reading the literature?

items.title:
Watch how most teams actually work today:

‚Üí One tool to generate images
‚Üí Another to edit video
‚Üí A...
items.content:
Watch how most teams actually work today:

‚Üí One tool to generate images
‚Üí Another to edit video
‚Üí Another for audio
‚Üí Another for stock assets

The hidden tax isn‚Äôt cost.
It‚Äôs cognitive load.

Every handoff breaks flow, consistency, and speed.
That‚Äôs where AI productivity quietly dies.
items.author: @Ronald_vanLoon
items.summary: Analysis that tool sprawl and context switching kills AI productivity, not the tools themselves
items.reasoning: Valid observation about AI tool fragmentation problem
items.summary_html: Analysis that tool sprawl and context switching kills AI productivity, not the tools themselves
items.content_html:
Watch how most teams actually work today:

‚Üí One tool to generate images

‚Üí Another to edit video

‚Üí Another for audio

‚Üí Another for stock assets

The hidden tax isn‚Äôt cost.

It‚Äôs cognitive load.

Every handoff breaks flow, consistency, and speed.

That‚Äôs where AI productivity quietly dies.

If you think AI will replace engineers, don't join my program.

items.content:
If you think AI will replace engineers, don't join my program.

You can keep waiting for the magic tool that will write production code without anyone's help.

But if you believe the engineers who understand how to build, deploy, and scale AI systems are the ones who will win, this is for you.

The next AI/ML Engineering cohort starts February 2, 2026.

I'm not going to hold your hand. I'm going to push you hard for 3 weeks and make you better than you thought possible.

You'll leave one order of magnitude smarter than when you joined.

Join at https://t.co/iZifcK7UTF.

items.summary: Promotional post for AI/ML Engineering cohort starting February 2, 2026, arguing engineers who understand AI systems will win over those waiting for replacement tools.
items.reasoning: Primarily promotional content for course. Contains opinion on AI-engineer relationship but framed around marketing.
items.summary_html: Promotional post for AI/ML Engineering cohort starting February 2, 2026, arguing engineers who understand AI systems will win over those waiting for replacement tools.
items.content_html:
If you think AI will replace engineers, don't join my program.

You can keep waiting for the magic tool that will write production code without anyone's help.

But if you believe the engineers who understand how to build, deploy, and scale AI systems are the ones who will win, this is for you.

The next AI/ML Engineering cohort starts February 2, 2026.

I'm not going to hold your hand. I'm going to push you hard for 3 weeks and make you better than you thought possible.

You'll leave one order of magnitude smarter than when you joined.

Join at https://t.co/iZifcK7UTF.

Follow @Airtable @Superagent
#SuperagentPartner #ad #SuperagentbyAirtable

What stood out for me is the process and what it was able to do.

A complex problem is first analyzed and broken down, then multiple specialized AI agents work in parallel on different dimensions, and their contributions are integrated into a single, coherent report. But not just any report.

The result wasn‚Äôt just more text, but an interactive, verifiable deliverable with scenarios, visual frameworks, and sources, ready to be used in real decision-making contexts.

items.content:
MIT: 35 best courses in machine learning! @MIT

Explore a world of knowledge with free online courses from MIT on edX, featuring lessons in AI, machine learning, computer science engineering, circuits and electronics, Genetics, data science, statistics and much more.  Many people are unaware that edX hosts an incredible collection of free online courses from some of the top educational institutions globally. You can dive into everything from AI to Python programming without any cost. A significant number of these courses are crafted by MIT experts.  We highly encourage you to take advantage of this opportunity, and to kickstart your learning journey, here‚Äôs a curated selection of the best free online courses from MIT that you can explore this month:

items.title: Highly rated book from @PacktDataML provides a great Guide to using OpenSearch and its many applicat...
items.content:
Highly rated book from @PacktDataML provides a great Guide to using OpenSearch and its many applications: https://t.co/354NCwC91R
 ‚òÖ ‚òÖ ‚òÖ ‚òÖ ‚òÖ 
Google says: "OpenSearch is an open-source search and analytics suite that provides scalable full-text search, real-time application monitoring, log analytics, security analytics, and vector database capabilities. Derived from Elasticsearch as a fork, it offers a community-driven, Apache 2.0-licensed solution for data-intensive applications, along with OpenSearch Dashboards for data visualization and exploration. OpenSearch is known for its high availability, performance, and flexibility, allowing users to analyze, visualize, and build data-driven applications across various use cases."
‚òÖ ‚òÖ ‚òÖ ‚òÖ ‚òÖ

ùìëùì∏ùì∏ùì¥  ùììùìÆùìºùì¨ùìªùì≤ùìπùìΩùì≤ùì∏ùì∑:
From seasoned data professionals managing billions of records to aspiring analysts exploring diverse datasets, this guide is for users at all levels who want to make the most of OpenSearch's capabilities and functionalities. Written by distinguished AWS Solutions Architects Jon Handler, Ph.D., a former search engine developer, Prashant Agrawal, a search specialist, and Soujanya Konka, an expert in large-scale data migrations, this guide brings together deep technical expertise with practical, hands-on knowledge of implementing OpenSearch in real-world scenarios.

Starting with an introduction to OpenSearch, you‚Äôll get to grips with the key features before delving into essential topics such as installing OpenSearch, ingesting data, crafting queries, visualizing results, ensuring security, and optimizing performance. Each concept is accompanied by practical examples and tutorials, allowing you to grasp the material through hands-on experience.

items.title:
From Stadium Networks to AI Coaches: How Tech Is Redefining Sports

Stadiums aren‚Äôt venues anymore‚Äît...
items.content:
From Stadium Networks to AI Coaches: How Tech Is Redefining Sports

Stadiums aren‚Äôt venues anymore‚Äîthey‚Äôre living networks.

In my latest article I explore this together with @TMobileBusiness as a partner to unpack how it works.

What‚Äôs changing (fast):

‚Üí Connectivity = infrastructure. Ticketing, POS, broadcast, and crowd flow ride one wireless fabric. Less friction, faster ops, happier fans.

‚Üí Broadcast explodes in perspectives. More angles, less latency, interactive feeds you can steer.

‚Üí One network, many workloads. Dynamic bandwidth for what matters now‚Äîgate surges, replay reviews, merch spikes. 

‚Üí Partnerships accelerate breakthroughs. Ref-cams, AR graphics, on-body antennas‚Äînone of these ships without tight cross-team engineering.

Check out the full article: https://t.co/wrx6ctxUzd 

Cc: @EvanKirstel | @Chels_LA | @antgrasso | @HaroldSinnott |

items.title:
#PaperADay 12
2019: Learning Latent Dynamics for Planning from Pixels (PlaNet)
https://t.co/BYK9pysM...
items.content:
#PaperADay 12
2019: Learning Latent Dynamics for Planning from Pixels (PlaNet)
https://t.co/BYK9pysMxu

This was the forerunner to the Dreamer 1/2/3/4 series of RL agents / papers, which I am going to read in sequence.

Planning is common in tasks with fully specified transition and reward dynamics like board games, but it is much more challenging when you have to learn the ‚Äúrules of the game‚Äù at the same time you are trying to improve your performance, especially when trying to do it from raw pixels instead of perfectly observed state features.

I sometimes semi-jokingly defend the position that ‚Äúplanning‚Äù might not actually be a thing, at least at low levels like this, and it just feels like planning when relevant experiences are called up from memory and bootstrap training on them results in changes to the current policy decision. There is a classic Atari paper that makes the case that replay buffers *are* a sort of non-parametric world model.

This paper gets peak performance ‚Äúclose to‚Äù strong model-free algorithms, but with far less real world experience necessary, because most of the work is happening in planning. Often, model based methods have to struggle to get to parity with the simpler model-free algorithms, and that is still going on with the Atari100k benchmark today.

This is a classic model-based system with a state transition and reward model. The biggest problem with transition models is usually that errors accumulate rapidly, so you can‚Äôt predict many steps into the future.

The transition models take a state plus an action, and predict the next state and the reward that results from taking the action. One of the key findings of the paper was that trying to learn a deterministic transition model basically failed. A stochastic model could be trained, but performance improved when they combined both deterministic and stochastic calculations in the model.

Looking closely at the video prediction frames in appendix H is interesting: once the deterministic GRU transition model lost the plot on a frame, everything after stayed broken, while the stochastic model could transition into something nonsensical on one frame, but then back to something sensible afterwards. I would not have guessed that. Their full combined model gave good looking predictions throughout.

There is no policy or value network as in model-free RL. Actions are selected by trying out a sequence of them using the modeled transition and reward functions, and the action that led to the best results is taken. Thousands of action sequences are evaluated for each action selected, but because they operate on compact latent vectors, this is relatively efficient. The Cross-Entropy Method (CEM) is used for planning multiple steps ahead with the transition models. This has to be heuristic for continuous action spaces or any more than a few modeled steps into the future.

The input to the state network is a 64x64 RGB observation (quantized to 5 bits like GLOW; I‚Äôm not clear why this is necessary). During training, they have an observation model that tries to go backwards from a state to a pixel observation. This is generally impossible to do perfectly when the state is smaller than the image, but attempting it provides a rich feedback signal for what to put in the state. This is not used for any part of the action decision process, it is just a training aid.

Action-repeat of 2 to 8, depending on the task.

Latent overshooting as a regularizer in latent space that encourages iterated one-step and multi-step predictions to match.
